docs.lead_paragraph: In the latest stage in New York City Transit's efforts to recover from the Jan. 23 fire that interrupted service to two subway lines, officials announced yesterday that full service was now restored. At first, riders of the two lines, the A and the C, were told to expect disruptions to last from three to five years, but that forecast was quickly adjusted after a public outcry. In fact, most service was restored on Feb. 1, months sooner than the adjusted forecast had indicated.

headline.main: Transit Officials Say Recovery From Jan. 23 Fire Is Complete

docs.snippet: In the latest stage in New York City Transit's efforts to recover from the Jan. 23 fire that interrupted service to two subway lines, officials announced yesterday that full service was now restored.

byline.original: By SEWELL CHAN; Colin Moynihan contributed reporting for this article

docs.lead_paragraph: GOLF Singh Elected to Hall of Fame Vijay Singh's arduous journey from Fiji reached another unimaginable destination yesterday when he was elected to the World Golf Hall of Fame.
docs.snippet: GOLF  Singh Elected to Hall of Fame      Vijay Singh's arduous journey from Fiji reached another unimaginable destination yesterday when he was elected to the World Golf Hall of Fame.

docs.lead_paragraph: The city official responsible for inmate health care at Rikers Island is planning to resign and has agreed to take a similar job in the Nassau County jail system, a spokeswoman for the city's Department of Health and Mental Hygiene said yesterday. James L. Capoziello, a deputy commissioner in charge of health services at the nine Rikers Island jails and two others, one in Lower Manhattan and the other in the Bronx, turned in his resignation on Monday and will leave his post in June, said the spokeswoman, Sandra Mullin.

headline.main: Health Supervisor for City Jails Resigning to Take Nassau Post

docs.snippet: The city official responsible for inmate health care at Rikers Island is planning to resign and has agreed to take a similar job in the Nassau County jail system, a spokeswoman for the city's Department of Health and Mental Hygiene said yesterday.

docs.lead_paragraph: My biking partner was in his 80's when he traded in his men's bicycle for a women's version because he could no longer swing his leg over the high bar. But at least he could still ride a bike. Others his age have far less physical mobility. Walking, rising from a chair, getting in and out of a car or bathtub, going up and down stairs, reaching for an item on a high shelf, even putting on shoes or an overhead shirt and buttoning a blouse are problems for many older adults who have what physical therapists call limited range of motion.

headline.main: Stretch Yourself (Your Joints and Muscles, Too)

docs.snippet: For older people with limited ranges of motion, exercise and stretching are a must.

docs.lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Paul Martin is scrambling to keep power as the scandal involving his Liberal Party grows, making deals that delay or even jettison central elements of his political agenda, including a bill to legalize same-sex marriages and a measure to control greenhouse gases. Less than a year after the Liberal government was elected, the House of Commons has virtually ground to a halt as leaders of Canada's four political parties, sensing the imminent fall of the government, have begun campaign posturing for elections that are rumored for June. Mr. Martin, it seems clear, hopes to delay elections until fall, expecting that public anger will cool by then.

headline.main: Canadian Leader Digs In to Confront Scandal

docs.abstract: Prime Min Paul Martin of Canada is making deals that delay or even jettison central elements of his political agenda in effort to remain in power as scandal involving his Liberal Party grows; House of Commons has virtually ground to halt as leaders of four political parties, sensing imminent fall of government, begin campaign posturing for elections rumored for June; Martin hopes to delay elections until fall, expecting that public anger will cool by then (M)
docs.snippet: Prime Minister Paul Martin is scrambling to keep power as the scandal involving his Liberal Party grows.

docs.lead_paragraph: Despite widespread belief in its usefulness, vitamin E supplements are no more effective than sugar pills for delaying the onset of Alzheimer's disease in people with mild memory changes, a study published this week in The New England Journal of Medicine suggests. The research also suggests that for certain patients the drug Aricept, previously shown to moderate the symptoms of Alzheimer's disease after it is diagnosed, may also work to delay its onset.

headline.main: Vitamin E Fails to Stop Progress of Alzheimer's

docs.snippet: Vitamin E supplements are no more effective than sugar pills for delaying the onset of Alzheimer's disease in people with mild memory changes, a study published this week in The New England Journal of Medicine suggests.

docs.lead_paragraph: FOR the first time in 20 years, local superintendents and school boards can formulate budgets that present a full picture of both revenues and expenditures. On May 17, when voters decide whether to approve the budgets for their local school districts, they will have accurate information about how much state aid has been allocated and what the tax levy will be. Just hours before its April 1 deadline, the State Legislature passed a budget on time for the first time in 21 years, and Gov. George E. Pataki approved it on Tuesday night. It provides $15.6 billion to public schools throughout the state, $848 million more than last year.
docs.abstract: Article on advantage that school districts on Long Island will have as result of State Legislature passing budget on time for first time in 21 years; Long Island school districts will receive nearly $2 billion in state aid, 13 percent of state total and increase of more than $107 million over last year

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Paul Krugman reports that nearly one-third of every American health care dollar is spent on administrative costs (''The Medical Money Pit,'' column, April 15). In my view, this is an underestimate because it does not include the hidden consumer costs of time, effort and frustration as we are caught in a vise between the billing errors of health care providers, insurance providers who don't want to provide and collection agencies who threaten our credit or worse if we don't personally pay up for disputes that are beyond our control.

headline.main: The True Costs Of Health Care

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Growing up watching my own mother struggle with illness without health insurance and seeing my father just now coming out of debt three years after her death, I am no stranger to the health care woes faced by too many Americans. But as a resident in internal medicine approaching 30, with only a 1989 Mazda to my name and debt in the high five figures, I take exception to Paul Krugman's assertion that part of the problem with the American health care system is that doctors are simply paid too much.

headline.main: The True Costs Of Health Care
